content.raw: Reviewing clobber, all the files and directories it attempts to overwrite seem to be specific to the init step. All files from run and finish are overwritten regardless of whether or not they exist. As such, I would recommend moving the option to the init step specifically, rather than having it global as it is now. Is this alright?
content.html: Reviewing clobber, all the files and directories it attempts to overwrite seem to be specific to the init step. All files from run and finish are overwritten regardless of whether or not they exist. As such, I would recommend moving the option to the init step specifically, rather than having it global as it is now. Is this alright?

content.raw: I think this is fine as long clobber actually removes all the intermediates as well. So if I had a training run along in any progression, if I run `train init --clobber` it will remove _everything_ and re-initialize. @hoffman might have some useful feedback regarding this option and the split steps.
content.html: I think this is fine as long clobber actually removes all the intermediates as well. So if I had a training run along in any progression, if I run train init --clobber it will remove everything and re-initialize. @hoffman might have some useful feedback regarding this option and the split steps.

content.raw: These refer to the details.sh and run.sh files in the log directory, not the individual files in the cmdline directory. These need to be appended since every time a new step is run, it adds new commands to each line. Perhaps the names are misleading and should be changed?

content.raw:
```python
def __init__(self, result_list = [None for _ in TRAIN_RESULT_TYPES]):
    zipper = zip(result_list, TRAIN_RESULT_TYPES.keys())
    for value, name in zipper:
        setattr(self, name, value)
```

In the TrainInstanceResults class, during initialization after training, we input a list and match it to keys from this ordered dict for saving. If this dict were not in this order, it would not match the input list.
content.html:
def __init__(self, result_list = [None for _ in TRAIN_RESULT_TYPES]):
    zipper = zip(result_list, TRAIN_RESULT_TYPES.keys())
    for value, name in zipper:
        setattr(self, name, value)

In the TrainInstanceResults class, during initialization after training, we input a list and match it to keys from this ordered dict for saving. If this dict were not in this order, it would not match the input list.

content.raw:
This code is alarming only because it sets attributes regardless of what is passed to it. As in - if future parameters are added in one part of the code, it will not be caught as an error in other parts or vice-versa.

It would be great to actually define what class members are expected here \(and set them to a default of None if required\).

Instead of initializing with a list of arbitrary arguments, you can set based on `**kwargs` if you wish for a more explicit and shorthand form of initialization.
content.html:
This code is alarming only because it sets attributes regardless of what is passed to it. As in - if future parameters are added in one part of the code, it will not be caught as an error in other parts or vice-versa.

It would be great to actually define what class members are expected here (and set them to a default of None if required).

Instead of initializing with a list of arbitrary arguments, you can set based on **kwargs if you wish for a more explicit and shorthand form of initialization.

content.raw: If the train directory is misspecified - then it will definitely throw an `IOError` where the error code is \`ENOENT\`. There probably needs to be some rethinking about how this error is checked.
content.html: If the train directory is misspecified - then it will definitely throw an IOError where the error code is `ENOENT`. There probably needs to be some rethinking about how this error is checked.

content.raw: This code is not changed from before, only moved to run for both train and identify. I’d make the argument that this is alright since a ENOENT will still be thrown later when triangulation is tried and the input.master and segway.str don’t exist. If there is a better solution to this though, maybe checking traindir.isdir\(\) immediately before this?
content.html: This code is not changed from before, only moved to run for both train and identify. I’d make the argument that this is alright since a ENOENT will still be thrown later when triangulation is tried and the input.master and segway.str don’t exist. If there is a better solution to this though, maybe checking traindir.isdir() immediately before this?

content.raw: I don’t think it’s worth checking those options just to do nothing, if you are iterating over those options, they will, by default, \(should\) be doing nothing.
content.html: I don’t think it’s worth checking those options just to do nothing, if you are iterating over those options, they will, by default, (should) be doing nothing.

content.raw:
`# bulk copy options that need no further processing `

`dst = cls.options_to_attrs[option] `

`res.set_option(dst, options_dict[option])`

In this section at the bottom of the for loop, we copy all the options to Runner. These are skipped since there won’t be a corresponding runner attr or it will have already been set.
content.html:
# bulk copy options that need no further processing

dst = cls.options_to_attrs[option]

res.set_option(dst, options_dict[option])

In this section at the bottom of the for loop, we copy all the options to Runner. These are skipped since there won’t be a corresponding runner attr or it will have already been set.

content.html: Then it should be restructured (see my elif statement below) so it’s obvious that these parameters are explicitly not copied on that final condition.

content.raw: If you are using `continue` you can just use `elif` \(and `else` for the end if you wish\) instead on these multiple clauses. I think you can reorganize the code this way so it’s obvious what should be conditional and what should happen on every iteration \(if anything\).
content.html: If you are using continue you can just use elif (and else for the end if you wish) instead on these multiple clauses. I think you can reorganize the code this way so it’s obvious what should be conditional and what should happen on every iteration (if anything).
